metadata.title: Alterations of White Matter Integrity in Subcortical Ischemic Vascular Disease with and Without Cognitive Impairment: a TBSS Study
metadata.abstract: Patients with subcortical ischemic vascular disease (SIVD) may exhibit a high risk of cognitive impairment (CI) by disruption of white matter (WM) integrity. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is recommended as a sensitive method to explore whole brain WM alterations at an asymptomatic stage of the disease, which might be correlated with underlying cognitive disorders. We aim to investigate alterations in WM microstructures and evaluate the relationships between the mean values of diffusion metrics (FA, MD, AD, and RD) and cognitive assessments in SIVD patients. Fifty SIVD patients with (SVCI, N  25) and without (pre-SVCI, N  25) cognitive impairments and normal controls (NC, N  23) underwent DTI and neuropsychological examinations. DTI data were analyzed via TBSS to detect significant changes in WM tracts. Spearman correlation analysis was performed to evaluate relationships between the mean values of diffusion indices and the cognitive assessments. In general, extensive symmetrically altered areas that involved approximately the entire cerebral WM were noted in the pre-SVCI group but were less distinct than that noted in the SVCI group compared with NCs. The genu of corpus callosum exhibited the most damaged WM fiber. Throughout WM, FA was decreased, whereas MD, AD, and RD were increased. Some specific WM tracts in patient groups were significantly correlated with the severity of white matter hyperintensity (WMH), cognitive assessments about executive functions and processing speed. WM integrity has already been damaged at the pre-SVCI stage, which would be associate with future cognitive dysfunction. DTI could potentially establish early biomarkers to detect underlying mechanisms of SIVD.

Introduction.text:
Subcortical ischemic vascular disease (SIVD) is the most common type of cerebral small vessel disease (cSVD), which is characterized by white matter lesions (WMLs), enlarged perivascular spaces (EPVSs), lacunar infarcts (LIs), and cerebral microbleeds (CMBs) in subcortical structures (Benjamin et al. 2016;Wardlaw et al. 2013). The consequences of SIVD include gait decline (van der Holst et al. 2018), cerebral complications (Yew et al. 2017), and vascular cognitive impairment (SVCI) especially with disorders in executive functions, attention, and mental processing speed (Lyoubi-Idrissi et al. 2017). Previous studies have revealed significant brain abnormalities in SIVD, including brain perfusion deficits in the temporal and frontal lobe, hippocampus, thalamus, and insula. These abnormalities are related to the degree of cognitive impairment (Sun et al. 2016), abnormal resting-state functional connectivity (FC) in the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), orbitofrontal lobe (OFL), and the inferior frontal gyrus, which are mainly involved in executive and memory functions (Zhou et al. 2016) and disruption of rich club organizations with lower network strength and efficiency that are associated with lower scores on psychomotor speed and executive functions (Tuladhar et al. 2017). However, the pathomechanisms of cognition injury in SIVD seem to be most closely related to diffuse areas of WM damage with neuronal loss, demyelination, and gliosis (D Souza et al. 2018). Such damages are likely to reduce the efficiency of gray matter connections and disrupt communication pathways Electronic supplementary material The online version of this article (https:doi.org10.1007s12031-019-01266-3) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.
between distinct brain regions, thus resulting in cognitive dysfunctions (Reijmer et al. 2016).
One promising technology to detect early WM alterations in SIVD is diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) (Zeestraten et al. 2017). Early studies demonstrated that DTI was more sensitive than traditional methods to investigate WM microstructure and integrity (Nitkunan et al. 2008;Xu et al. 2010). Several studies have reported that both lacunes and diffuse WM damage detected in DTI are associated with cognitive impairment (Lawrence et al. 2013;Yuan et al. 2017). Thus, DTI could be applied as a sensitive method to explore the neural mechanism underlying cognitive impairment. To provide a comprehensive view of the patterns of change in WM and its relationship with cognitive functions, four main diffusion metrics, including the fractional anisotropy (FA), the mean diffusivity (MD), the axial diffusivity (AD), and the radial diffusivity (RD), are conjointly calculated to provide more information about reduced myelination and loss of axons (Amlien and Fjell 2014;Shu et al. 2011;Soares et al. 2013).
Recent studies have demonstrated that patients with cognitive impairment exhibited decreased FA, increased MD, and different combination of changes in AD and RD of WM tracts especially located in thalamic-and caudate-prefrontal pathways, such as the corpus callosum (CC) and anterior thalamic radiation (ATR), which are significantly related to the neuropsychological assessments of executive function and processing speed (Biesbroek et al. 2017). However, most studies mainly focus on patients with cognitive impairment (SVCI) or dementia (VaD) but neglect the asymptomatic stage of disease when individuals suffer vascular damage without cognitive impairments, which might represent a high-risk period of future cognition decline (pre-SVCI) (Sachdev et al. 2014).
Tract-based spatial statistics (TBSS) is a reliable and optimized method with no bias and automation advantages (Smith et al. 2006) that can be used to comprehensively understand WM fiber damage across the entire brain. We investigated the extent of the changes in the microstructure of major WM tracts using TBSS and evaluated relationships between the diffusion metrics (FA, MD, AD, and RD) and cognitive disturbances in SIVD patients.

Participants.text:
The recruitment occurred between 2017 and 2018 at the first affiliated hospital of Chongqing Medical University. In total, 73 participants were recruited, including fifty SIVD patients with (SVCI, N  25) and without (pre-SVCI, N  25) cognitive impairments and normal controls matched for age, gender, and education (NC, N  23). Each subject signed an informed consent and the study was approved by the Ethics Committee of our university.
Patients with SIVD met the following criteria (Roman et al. 2002): (1) white matter lesions: hyperintensities extending into periventricular and deep white matter; extending caps ( 10 mm as measured parallel to ventricle) or irregular halo ( 10 mm with broad, irregular margins and extending into deep white matter); and diffusely confluent hyperintensities ( 25 mm, irregular shape) or extensive white matter change (diffuse hyperintensity without focal lesions); (2) lacunar cases: multiple lacunas ( 5) in the deep gray matter and at least moderate white matter lesions; (3) absence of hemorrhages, cortical andor territorial infarcts and watershed infarcts; signs of normal pressure hydrocephalus; and specific causes of white matter lesions.
The pre-SVCI group met the following criteria: (1) in accordance with the criteria of SIVD; (2) normal daily life activities and cognitive assessments; (3) a Clinical Dementia Rating Scale (CDR) score  0; (4) a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score  27.
The diagnosis of SVCI was made according to the following criteria (Galluzzi et al. 2005) The criteria for the NC were as follows: (1) no neurological and psychiatric disorders, (2) no abnormal findings on the conventional brain MR imaging, and (3) no cognitive complaints.
The exclusion criteria for all of the subjects included the following: (1) metabolic conditions, such as hypothyroidism or folic acid deficiencies; (2) psychiatric disorders, such as schizophrenia or depression; (3) Parkinsonian syndrome, epilepsy, and other nervous system diseases that influence cognitive functions. Anyone with a metallic foreign body or other relevant MR scanning contraindications was excluded from the study.
In addition, the visual Fazekas scale was used on FLAIR images to rate the severity of white matter hyperintensities (WMH) (Fazekas et al. 1987).

Neuropsychological Assessment.text: All participants underwent a comprehensive neuropsychological battery. The following cognitive variables were included in the present analysis: ( 1

MRI Acquisition.text: MRI scanning was performed on a GE Signa Hdxt 3.0T scanner using an eight-channel phased-array head coil. Foam padding was used to restrict head movement, and ear plugs were used to minimize the scanner noise. Subjects were told to relax, keep their eyes closed, and remain awake. The scan parameters of the high-resolution 3D-T 1 were as follows: TR  8.3 ms, TE  3.3 ms, flip angle  15, thicknessgap  1.00 mm, field of view (FOV)  240  240 mm, matrix  240  240, voxel  1  1  1 mm 3 , and acquisition time  6.45 min. The scan parameters of the T 2 -FLAIR-weighted imaging were as follows: TR  8000 ms, TE  126 ms, TI  1500 ms, thicknessgap  5.01.5 mm, FOV  240  240 mm, and matrix  256  192. DTI data were obtained using single shot spin echo-echo planar imaging (SS-SE-EPI) sequences in 30 independent, non-collinear directions of b  1000 and 0 smm 2 with the following parameters: TR  1100 ms, TE  77.6 ms, matrix  128  128, FOV  256  256 mm 2 , slices  45, thickness  3 mm.

Data Preprocessing.text: DTI data analyses were performed using the Functional MRI of the Brain Software Library (FSL) version 5.0.9 (http:fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk). First, the FMRIBs nonlinear image registration tool was used to affine-aligned each diffusion-weighted volume to its corresponding b 0 image and corrected for possible motion artifacts and eddycurrent distortions. Then, the non-brain tissue was removed using the brain extraction tool with a fractional threshold of 0.2. Finally, DTIfit within FSL was used to create FA, MD, AD, and RD images at each brain voxel (Smith 2002).

Tract-Based Spatial Statistics (TBSS).text: The steps of the TBSS analyses were as follows (Smith et al. 2006): (1) Using FSLs nonlinear image registration algorithm, the FA maps of each subject was aligned into FMRIB58_FA standard space. (2) Then, a mean FA image was generated, and the mean FA skeleton, which represents the core-structure of the WM tracts, was created by thinning the mean FA image. (3) Individual subjects FA images were projected onto the mean FA skeleton. These skeleton projection factors were also applied to the MD, AD, and RD images.

Statistical Analysis.text:
Demographic information, clinical parameters, and cognitive test scores were compared among three groups using SPSS 23.0 software. One-way ANOVA analysis and post hoc multiple comparisons were used to assess differences in the continuous variables across the groups. The Kruskal-Wallis H test was used for nonparametric data, and the chi-square test was used to analyze the sex proportions.
In the TBSS data, the nonparametric permutation analysis (randomize) tool was employed to compare the FA, MD, AD, and RD among three groups. The design matrix included WMH scores, age, gender, and education as nuisance covariates (Winkler et al. 2014). The number of permutation tests was set at 5000, and the significance threshold was set at P  0.05 Familywise Error Rate (FWE) corrected for multiple comparisons using the threshold-free cluster enhancement (TFCE) option. John Hopkins University (JHU) WM atlas was used to identify the location of WM tracts that contained the clusters with significant differences and parcel them into different region of interests (ROIs).
Spearman correlation analysis controlling for age, gender, and education was performed to explore the relationships between the mean values of diffusion indices and cognitive assessments. All of the statistical tests were two-tailed, and P  0.05 was set as the level of statistical significance. Due to multiple testing, Bonferroni correction was used to adjust P values (P c  0.0042).

Demographic and Cognitive Characteristic.text: Demographic and clinical characteristics of the participants are presented in Table 1. Compared with the NC group, the pre-SVCI group and SVCI group exhibited significantly increased systolic blood pressure. Within the patient group, significant differences in systolic blood pressure and WMH were noted. No significant differences in age, gender, education, fasting glucose levels, and diastolic blood pressure among the three groups. Table 2 presents the cognitive assessment results. The SVCI group exhibited the worst results of the MMSE and tests of the cognitive domains compared with the other two groups. The pre-SVCI group performed significantly worse on the TMT-B test compared with the NC group.

TBSS Analysis.text:
TBSS analysis based on the results of ANOVA controlled for age, gender, education, and WMH demonstrated extensively symmetrical white matter impairment among the three groups (P  0.05, FWE corrected), including the genu of corpus callosum, splenium of corpus callosum, superior longitudinal fasciculus, inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, anterior thalamic radiation, inferior longitudinal fasciculus, and corticospinal tract. Compared with the NC group, the pre-SVCI and SVCI groups exhibited significantly reduced FA and significantly increased MD, AD, and RD in brain regions. The pattern of increased AD in WM areas appeared more localized compared with the other three indices (Fig. 1). Table 3 illustrates the numbers and percentage of total significant voxels in the FA, MD, AD, and RD regions. The genu of corpus callosum was the most affected WM tract of the total significant voxels.
Regarding within-group analysis, Fig. 2 demonstrates that the pre-SVCI group exhibited significantly reduced FA in the left inferior longitudinal fasciculus, bilateral inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, left inferior longitudinal fasciculus, and bilateral anterior thalamic radiation compared with the NC group, and the SVCI group exhibited similar regional WM disruptions compared with the other two groups. Discussion.text:
In the current study, we evaluated WM alterations in SIVD patients with (SVCI) and without (pre-SVCI) cognitive impairment compared with the well-matched NC group using the TBSS method. The results demonstrated that patients with SIVD exhibit extensive areas of microstructural changes mostly in WM fibers, including the genu and splenium of the corpus callosum, bilateral inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, superior longitudinal fasciculus, inferior longitudinal fasciculus, and bilateral anterior thalamic radiation and corticospinal tract. Compared with the NCs, the pre-SVCI group exhibited widespread damage in whole brain WM skeletons, but the damage was less distinct compared with that noted in the SVCI group. The SIVD group exhibited significantly reduced FA and increased MD, AD, and RD in multiple WM regions. The genu of corpus callosum was the most affected WM tracts in the early stage of the disease. We also found that mean values of diffusion indices in some specific WM tracts in patient groups were significantly correlated with the burden of WMH and neuropsychological assessments that concerned executive functions. SIVD is a heterogeneous group of diseases that is characterized by extensive cerebral WM lesions and lacunar infarcts (Rosenberg et al. 2014). The pathologies of the disease could disrupt the global connection between cortical and subcortical networks, resulting in vascular cognitive impairment by damaging the intensity of the WM fibers, increasing the extracellular space and secondarily leading to atrophy of the gray cortex (Zeestraten et al. 2017). In the present study, we found that the WM microstructure was already impaired, mainly in cognitive and sensorimotor-related WM fibers at the early stage of SIVD. These findings were consistent with previous studies (Kim et al. 2015;Tuladhar et al. 2015). The underlying mechanisms of the disease may be related to the loss of myelin and axon damage from microvascular pathology (Joutel and Chabriat 2017), so we evaluated diffusion indices to explore the possible pathologic characteristics and revealed significantly reduced FA and increased MD in widespread WM tracts. Based on previous studies, FA represents the integrity of nerve fibers and has been used as an indicator reflecting WM tract damage (Wang et al. 2017), whereas MD represents a condition with reduced barriers to free water diffusion (Alves et al. 2015). The combination of reduced FA and increased MD may reflect the progressive loss of intensity of WM. We also found increased AD and RD in WM tracts, suggesting lesion-related axonal damage and demyelination contributing to WM impairment (Huang et al. 2018;Sun et al. 2018). The DTI-derived indices revealed more diffuse abnormalities of MD and RD compared with FA and AD (Fig. 2). Moreover, the mean MD values of the right SLF and left IFOF in the SVCI group were significantly correlated with WMH scores (shown in Supplement Table ), which is consistent with previous studies that concluded the MD was more sensitive for the progression of cerebral vascular disease compared with FA. MD and RD might serve as early markers of demyelination in WM regions (Hulst et al. 2013;van der Holst et al. 2018). The post hoc analysis demonstrated that the SVCI group exhibited more pronounced WM tissue disruption compared with the other two groups, which implied more serious axonal damage and myelin loss during disease progression. DTI approaches could be utilized as a remarkable method to detect early alterations of WM tracts at the prodromal stage of SIVD and additionally evaluate the severity of WM alterations.
We confirmed that specific WM tracts related to cognitive function were particularly vulnerable to SIVD. The mean values of diffusion indices in bilateral ILF and right SLF in the pre-SVCI group exhibited a significantly positive correlations with the cognitive assessments (R-DST, TMT-B, and stoop-1 test), which were considered acknowledgement tests to evaluate speed processing and executive functions (Ciulli et al. 2016;Palta et al. 2016). SLF and ILF are the major association fibers that connect frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital cortices involved in executive functions and processing speed (Biesbroek et al. 2017). In the SVCI group, we also identified that the mean values of diffusion parameters in the bilateral ATR, a complex projection system that involves ascending fibers from the thalamus to the cerebral cortex and descending fibers from the fronto-parietal cortex to subcortical nuclei (Duering et al. 2013), were significantly negative related with the Stroop-1 test and CDT. Our results suggested that prefrontal-subcortical projections and long association tracts connecting strategic cognitive-related brain regions were susceptible to SIVD interruptions, and these findings are consistent with other relevant studies (Duering et al. 2014). The GCC exhibited WM tracts that were highly influenced at the early stage of SIVD. These results confirmed that cerebral vascular disease could lead to the loss of microstructure integrity of the GCC. These commissural fibers connecting the frontal lobe and other multiple cortical areas involved in attention and executive functions were ultimately impaired (Reginold et al. 2016). However, we observed no relationship between the mean valued of diffusion indices in GCC and cognitive assessments, which were inconsistent with the previous studies (Sun et al. 2018). This finding might be explained by the fact that we recruited some SIVD patients without cognitive impairments, and the early phase of the disease might only cause slight alterations in cognitive function. Other significant relationships between WM tracts and neuropsychological tests might be demonstrated by the fact that SIVD lesions impact WM fibers not only confined to some certain areas but along with the entire fiber skeleton.
There are several limitations to this study. First, the study included a relatively limited sample size and involved crosssectional research, which might lead to reduced sensitivity and accuracy of the results. Second, the severity of the disease in SIVD patients were rather mild, thus the underlying mechanism of the disease seems to be incompletely understood. In addition, some correlations between the WM tracts and cognitive assessments (shown in Supplement Table ) were not significant following Bonferroni multiple comparisons, indicating that these studies should only be considered an exploratory analysis. Future longitudinal follow-up studies with a larger scale and moderate-severe SIVD subjects are needed to provide comprehensive insight into the pathophysiology of the disease and statistical power. Third, WMH scores served as a covariate in the randomized analysis according to the Fazekas standard. Therefore, future studies with advanced methods, such as semiautomatic algorithm approaches, are recommended to strength the accuracy and reliability of our results.
In conclusion, this study indicated that SIVD patients exhibited extensive WM damage at the early stage of the disease, especially the GCC. Moreover, WM disruptions in bilateral ILF and right SLF of the pre-SVCI group and bilateral ATR of the SVCI group seemed to be closely related to cognitive assessments regarding executive functions and processing speed. Using TBSS analyses, we generated a global map of the WM changes in SIVD patients by measuring anisotropy and diffusivity alterations across the brain. DTI could be regarded as a sensitive tool for exploring the mechanisms of cognitive dysfunction in SIVD, especially during the early stage of the disease.
